thread.title_full: Parker Posey Cast as Dr. Smith in Netflix's Lost In Space Reboot

posts.author: Jay Jayson
posts.title: Parker Posey Cast as Dr. Smith in Netflix's Lost In Space Reboot
posts.text:
Parker Posey Cast as Dr. Smith in Netflix's Lost In Space Reboot Jay Jayson Tweet This 
Parker "Queen of the Indies" Posey, who is best known to mainstream audiences for her memorable supporting roles in 1993's Dazed and Confused and 2006's Superman Returns , will play a gender-bent version of Dr. Smith in Netflix's Lost in Space reboot. 
Jonathan Harris portrayed the selfish, lazy, and sometimes-wicked Dr. Zachary Smith in the original 1965 television series. To prevent the Robinsons from successfully carrying out their mission to colonize a planet orbiting the nearest star, Alpha Centauri, Dr. Smith — a surgeon, a psychologist, and a secret-agent — sabotaged the Jupiter 2 spacecraft, causing it to become lost in... (Now, where was it again? Oh, yeah.) Space! Unintentionally, Smith became trapped aboard the ship. 
Gary Oldman ( Batman Begins ) portrayed the character in the forgettable 1998 film. 
Posey joins a cast that already features Molly Parker ( House of Cards ) as Maureen Robinson, Toby Stephens ( Black Sails ) as John Robinson, Maxwell Jenkins ( Sense8 ) as Will Robinson, and Taylor Russell ( Falling Skies ) as Judy Robinson. 
Taking its cues from the original series, the show centers around the Robinson family, who is forced to come together in a time of crisis. Stranded light years from their intended destination, they find themselves battling a strange new alien environment and also their own personal demons. Equal parts family drama and sci-fi adventure, it is a survival story for the ages. 
Zack Estrin ( Prison Break ) serves as executive producer alongside writers Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless ( Dracula Untold , Last Witch Hunter ); Synthesis Entertainment’s Kevin Burns ( The Curse of Oak Island , Ancient Aliens ) and Jon Jashni ( Godzilla , Pacific Rim ); and Applebox’s Emmy®-nominated director Neil Marshall ( Game of Thrones , The Descent ) and Marc Helwig. Marshall is also set to direct several episodes of the series. Lost in Space is a Legendary TV production for Netflix. 
10-episode first season of the one-hour sci-fi drama, from Legendary TV, will premiere worldwide on Netflix in 2018.

thread.title: 11 Thanksgiving Movies on Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime
thread.title_full: 11 Thanksgiving Movies on Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime | Glamour

posts.author: Lynsey Eidell
posts.title: 11 Thanksgiving Movies on Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime
posts.text:
In between your marathon eating session and before the inevitable tryptophan coma, we have the perfect Turkey Day activity to squeeze in: cozying up on the couch with a movie. And not just any movie, of course—but a Thanksgiving-themed one at that. From memorable meal scenes to cult hits to holiday horrors, digest with these 11 Thanksgiving movies that are available to stream right now on Netflix , Hulu , and Amazon Prime .
Miracle on 34th Street
We're not trying to sneak in a Christmas movie prematurely—never forget that this feel-good movie actually kicks off with the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade, when Kris Kringle has to fill in for a drunk Santa. Available on Netflix.
Dutch
Your Thanksgiving travels will seem like a breeze when you watch this 1991 movie about Dutch (Ed O'Neill), who offers to bring his girlfriend's bratty son home from his prep school in Atlanta all the way to Chicago. Available on Netflix.
Kristy
Turkey Day meets Halloween in this horror movie about a girl who opts to stay at college over Thanksgiving break, only to be hunted by a gang of sadistic attackers. An added bonus: Watching scary movies is said to burn calories . Available on Netflix.
Son in Law
Bringing home a significant other for the holiday? Be sure to watch Pauly Shore as a crazy, college party animal who visits his girlfriend's small town for Thanksgiving as a lesson in what not to do. Available on Netflix.
The Doors
Jim Morrison's Thanksgiving will make you feel better about any turkey mishap you've ever had (trust). Available on Netflix.
Addams Family Values
Watch Wednesday (Christina Ricci) school everyone in the real story behind Thanksgiving while at summer camp. Available on Amazon Prime and Hulu.
The Object of My Affection
Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd's adorable, complicated, sexually-charged friendship comes to a pinnacle on—you guessed it—Thanksgiving. Available on STARZ on Amazon.
Boogeyman
Need more scares to burn off that extra serving of pie? Watch Barry Watson (of 7th Heaven fame) fight against a terrorizing boogeyman after a Thanksgiving trip with his girlfriend. Available on STARZ on Amazon.
Rocky
Who can forget Paulie ruining the turkey—and opening the door for Rocky and Adrian to have the sweetest first date (and first kiss) on Thanksgiving? Available on Hulu.
Rescue Dawn
Watching these Vietnam War POWs daydream about Thanksgiving dinners will make you even more thankful this year. Available on Hulu.
Holiday Engagement
When your fiancé breaks up with you right before Thanksgiving, you obviously hire an actor to pose as your husband-to-be for your trip home for Thanksgiving. (We bet you can guess where this is going.) Available on Hulu.
Related: Here are more Thanksgiving movies we love .

thread.title: Coursera embraces Netflix subscription model for course access
thread.title_full: Coursera embraces Netflix subscription model for course access

posts.author: admin
posts.title: Coursera embraces Netflix subscription model for course access
posts.text:
by Autumn A. Arnett, Education Dive 
Coursera is shifting away from a pay-by-the-course model towards a monthly subscription plan to encourage “binge learning,” Financial Times reports. An initial pilot of the program found a 250% increase in course completion. The company’s chief product officer, who came to Coursera from Netflix, told Financial Times, “We’re not introducing a new payment model so much as a new psychological model,” saying learners are financially motivated to complete more courses faster. The new payment model will apply to any specialization area that includes six to eight courses on one subject. Prices will range from $39-$89 per month — previously, learners paid between $19-$99 per course.

thread.title: Gilmore Girls revival cast reveals how they got back into character - Entertainment Weekly
thread.title_full: Gilmore Girls revival cast reveals how they got back into character - Entertainment Weekly

posts.title: Gilmore Girls revival cast reveals how they got back into character - Entertainment Weekly
posts.text:
'Gilmore Girls': 5 Exclusive Photos From the Netflix Revival 
With Netflix’s upcoming four-part Gilmore Girls revival, titled Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life , a large number of the show’s original cast members were given the opportunity to reinhabit the characters they said goodbye to years ago. However, getting back into character after eight years is an experience every actor approached differently. 
As far as Lauren Graham and Kelly Bishop were concerned, snapping back into the mindsets of their Stars Hollow — or Hartford, Connecticut — counterpart was simple. “To pick it up again felt really kind of inevitable,” Graham tells EW of playing Lorelai. “[It was] definitely easy in most ways.” 
For Bishop, Emily Gilmore was easy to tap back into because she never went anywhere. “She’s been there all along,” Bishop says. “She travels around with me, so as far as Emily’s personality and her character, it was just waiting for me to climb into the suit and zip it up.” 
But not everyone made such a seamless transition. For many of the returning actors, it was about preparation, putting in the work before returning to set. “I thought a lot about it and what I wanted to bring to the character now that would be different from where we left off,” Alexis Bledel says of Rory. “I mostly just imagined where she’s been since we left off, what she’s been doing, how that’s shaped her.” 
Ironically, it was Jared Padalecki, who plays Dean, who took the most Rory-esque approach to his preparation: Research, research, research. “I watched a few of those first seasons,” Padalecki says. “I wanted to see what my initial take was on the character. I tried to study who I was and who I wanted Dean to be. I really focused on seasons 2 and 3, not 4 and 5 as much because Dean was embroiled in controversies. I got to focus on the parts of Dean that I liked the most and thought stood the test of time.” 
Then there’s Matt Czuchry, who focused first on reacquainting himself with the pace of the show’s dialogue, and then from there, tried to tap into the mental state of Logan Huntzberger. “Logan’s in a different place in his life,” Czuchry says. “The relationships that he has throughout these four chapters are in a different place, so there was a lot of preparation that went into that to get into that headspace. At the same time, what I love about all four chapters that Amy [Sherman-Palladino] and Dan [Palladino] wrote is that it’s just so perfect in terms of where the characters have been, where they are now, and where they’re going. So in some ways, once we did that preparation, when I got on set, it felt like we had never left.” 
Watch EW Reunites: Gilmore Girls here now on the new People/Entertainment Weekly Network (PEN). Go to PEOPLE.com/PEN , or download the PEN app on Apple TV, Roku Players, Amazon Fire TV, Xumo, Chromecast, iOS, and Android devices. 
Speaking of getting back on set, for Scott Patterson, reconnecting with Luke didn’t happen until he was standing foot in the diner. Actually, it happened right after that. “I got on set the first day, walked into the diner, started rehearsing a scene, and I just didn’t have it,” Scott Patterson says. “I think I came in there with some overconfidence, and it just wasn’t there for me. So I asked Amy if I could just take a break so I could stroll around Stars Hollow. I walked around and tried to relive some of the moments, really take it in. And that actually worked. I got the walk back, and I just felt like him, and then after that, it was a breeze.” 
Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life hits Netflix on Friday, Nov. 25.

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls' women are back in new 4-part Netflix series
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls' women are back in new 4-part Netflix series

posts.author: Rick Bentley, Fresno Bee
posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls' women are back in new 4-part Netflix series
posts.text:
Duluth School Board rejects pay raise for staff 
After seven seasons and 154 episodes of watching the lives of Lorelai and Rory Gilmore unfold among family and friends, "Gilmore Girls" came to an end. Fans wept. 
The voices are back on Netflix in the four-part series "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life." The story is told through 90-minute chapters — each spanning one season: winter, spring, summer, fall. Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel headline the returning cast that features some very familiar faces to fans of the show. 
It's been almost a decade but Graham and Bledel found it easy to slip back into their mother-daughter world. 
"It was literally like no time had passed. It was not difficult. It was easy. It was joyous. It was fun. It was exhilarating. It was the old show. I mean, there was no sense of having to resuscitate something. It was just like it was meant to continue," Graham says. 
One reason it was so easy to return was that conversations about "Gilmore Girls" never stopped, despite the cast going off to do other roles. That's why both actors signed on to reprise their roles even before scripts had been written. 
It didn't hurt that those scripts would be penned by series creator Amy Sherman-Palladino. The energetic writer and producer, along with her husband Dan Palladino, had left the series before the start of the seventh, and final, season. 
One conversation with the fast-talking Sherman-Palladino and it's obvious the rapid fire conversations on the series are of her making. Bledel says slipping back into playing Rory was a breeze because Sherman-Palladino's writing gives an actor all the information they need to play the role. 
A simple question to Sherman-Palladino about returning to the sets on the Warner Bros. lot ignites a verbal barrage. 
"(Expletive deleted), they changed our Stars Hollow. They got a deal on brown paint. I've never seen so much brown paint in my entire life. I'm like, 'Who the (expletive deleted) doesn't want some color in your town?' There wasn't any red. There wasn't any yellow," Sherman-Palladino says. "There wasn't a posy. There was still the sidewalks that we put in. They're cracked. So we had to go back in and zhoosh up Stars Hollow. We had to rebuild all the sets. I just remember the day that Scott (Patterson) walked into Luke's Diner for the first time, because it wasn't Luke's Diner. It's the 'Pretty Little Liars' are lying in there constantly now. So we had to get the lies out and put the diner back in." 
Bledel had a few conversations over the years away from Stars Hollow where Sherman-Palladino told here that she still loved the characters and wanted to explore stories with them. 
The actor knows "The Gilmore Girls" is Sherman-Palladino's vision. The only thing Bledel wanted to make sure happened in the new episodes was a reveal that all of the hard work Rory had gone through in those 154 episodes had paid off. 
Bledel is coy when she talks about where her character's love life has gone. She does say that all of her ex-boyfriends make an appearance. 
For years, both Graham and Bledel have had people approach them lamenting the loss of the program. A major reason for the feeling of loss was the relationship the Gilmore mom and daughter had. 
"More people than I would have ever thought said it was the same relationship they have with their mother or daughter," Graham says. "I would think, 'Wow, you must be really cool.' I think people see themselves in the characters more than they don't. That probably has to do at least in part with us being here. Some of those daughters are now mothers and the cycle begins again." 
"Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" 
12:01 a.m. Friday, Netflix

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls' stars Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel dish on new Netflix episodes
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls' stars Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel dish on new Netflix episodes - Press Enterprise

posts.author: ROB LOWMAN
posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls' stars Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel dish on new Netflix episodes
posts.text:
By ROB LOWMAN Nov. 24, 2016 Updated: 3:04 p.m. 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life' What: Four new 90-minute episodes update the series with original stars Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel.
When: All episodes drop at 12:01 a.m. Friday, Nov. 25
Where: Netflix
Can you go home again? Will they still love you? Will it feel the same?
These are questions “Gilmore Girls” and its fans are asking.
The beloved series that ran 2000-’07 on the WB and later CW networks has been revived for four hotly anticipated 90-minute chapters, each launching globally on Netflix Friday .
When “Gilmore Girls” debuted, it told the story of a close relationship between a 32-year-old mother (Lauren Graham as Lorelai Gilmore) and her 16-year-old daughter (Alexis Bledel as Rory Gilmore). Their stories were often entwined in the lives of the eccentric characters in their cozy town of Stars Hollow, Conn., and visits to Luke’s Diner.
“It’s amazing to know that people are eagerly awaiting the release of these episodes and have loved the show all these years,” says Bledel, 35.
“I think it’s because it’s extremely comforting in a world that is lacking comfort,” says Graham, 49, about the enduring appeal of “GG.”
Under the heading “A Year in the Life,” the four new episodes will bring back a number of the original characters, including Emily Gilmore, Lorelai’s tough mother (Kelly Bishop) and Luke Danes, owner of the diner and Lorelai’s other half (Scott Patterson). The new series also will pay tribute to the late Edward Herrmann, who played Lorelai’s father. The actor died in 2014.
The four episodes – written, directed and executive produced by series creator Amy Sherman-Palladino – depict each season over a year in Stars Hollow. Of course, nothing much happens in the picturesque berg. The installation of a new sewer system is the issue at hand, but “Gilmore Girls” always provided an emotional landscape for its fans.
At its heart, it always has been about the incredible bond of love between Lorelai and Rory, which is rendered so engagingly that it’s fair to say everyone might wish to have a relationship like that.
“It’s not a story about a little girl who’s in high school anymore,” says Graham about the new show. “It’s a story about a young woman and kind of the struggles she faces.”
Yet the actress notes that the dynamics between Lorelai and her mother and between Lorelai and Rory remain the same even if they have grown older.
In the original story, the young Lorelai had fled her disapproving parents in upscale Hartford at 16 to give birth to a daughter, Rory, and remake her life in Stars Hollow.
As warm as Rory’s relationship is with Lorelai, the one between Rory’s mother and grandmother is chilly. Often, Rory finds herself trying to make peace between them, and as she grew older, tried to find her place between the two strong women.
The storyline for the new season finds all three of the Gilmore women facing new challenges in their lives. Though Rory graduated from Yale and began a career in journalism when the series ended in 2007, she now finds herself unable to land a full-time job and must scramble around freelancing.
Lorelai is still with Luke, but she is unsure about what to do with her life and feels somewhat in a rut. Emily finds herself alone and still coping with the death of her husband.

thread.title: 6 Excellent New Comedy Specials You Can Watch on Netflix Right Now
thread.title_full: 6 Excellent New Comedy Specials You Can Watch on Netflix Right Now

posts.title: 6 Excellent New Comedy Specials You Can Watch on Netflix Right Now
posts.text:
6 Excellent New Comedy Specials You Can Watch on Netflix Right Now By Netflix The best of 2016, all in one place. 
This year has been rough. We lost Glenn (R.I.P.), Cruel Winter still isn’t on Spotify, and, of course, you know, the thing happened . If you’re like me, you’re probably using this Thanksgiving break to R&R, and right now you could probably use a good laugh. Luckily, Netflix has been on a roll with its comedy specials. If you logged on right now your biggest problem would be figuring out where to start. EDITOR’S PICK Your Thanksgiving Netflix Guide: What to Binge-Watch After You Binge-Eat 
Luckily, after watching hundreds of one-liners, impersonations, and crude sex jokes I’ve whittled 2016’s Netflix comedy specials down to the six essentials. Between these half dozen comedians there’s something for everybody. Their material ranges from witty to raunchy to like, super meta . So log off your newsfeeds for a while and grab a beer and a spot on the couch. Bo Burnham: Make Happy 
Of all the specials on this list, Bo Burnham’s Make Happy is the most likely to become a classic. It’s a daring work, one that sees the 25-year old polymath exploring much heavier themes than in his in past routines. But every time Burnham pushes the audience into uncomfortable territory, like mental illness or white male privilege, it pays off with major laughs and incredible music. 
His songs are flawless (even his nursery rap over a Metro Boomin-esque trap beat could probably chart), and his prevailing theme—that most entertainment only offers temporary relief from the harsh truths of the world—is thoughtful, if a little too real at times. Joe Rogan: Triggered 
Joe Rogan performs the entirety of Triggered while extraordinarily stoned. For those familiar with his podcast, “The Joe Rogan Experience,” this probably isn’t a surprise. But, given how many witty ideas he packs into 63 minutes, they must smoke some serious stuff in California. 
With a name like “Triggered,” you already know Rogan isn’t afraid to ruffle a few feathers–i.e. his backhanded reason for wanting a woman president: “That way we can realize chicks can't do that fucking job either.” Yet Rogan is thoughtful enough that his less PC musings aren’t wantonly offensive. Overall, he’s more focused on figuring out why weed gummy bears are so strong than pushing some sort of agenda. 
Triggered works because it makes you feel like you’re hanging out with your smartest stoner friend. Rogan has a way with weaving brainy observations into goofy stories, and his transitions are razor-sharp for a guy with such a passion for being blunted. (His abrupt segue into a story of his life-changing dolphin encounter made me spit my drink.) Rogan leaves the special on a high note–and you’ll laugh whether or not you’re up there with him. Ali Wong: Baby Cobra 
It’s rare to see a comedian perform 7½ months pregnant. Rarer still is for that fact to be one of the less shocking elements of their set. See, in Baby Cobra , Ali Wong (whose work as a writer on Fresh Off the Boat you’ve laughed at before) holds nothing back. In her words “When you’re pregnant, you’re hungry, tired, and fat, so you have this ‘I don’t give a fuck’ attitude that lends itself very well to performance.” 
The 34-year old Vietnamese-Chinese-American comedian specializes in the kind of comedy that makes you wince and laugh at once. At one point she recounts an accidental hookup with a homeless guy, at another she delves into the joys of anal sex. While I suppose the rules of TMI are suspended for a comedy routine, she walks the line with finesse. 
Wong is clearly aware that comedy is generally a boys’ club. But by doubling down on her unique perspective, she tells stories most other comedians would never think of with a raunchiness they wouldn’t dare match. Kathleen Madigan: Bothering Jesus 
If you’re looking for a special you can enjoy without worrying if Mom wanders into the living room, Bothering Jesus is your best bet. Kathleen Madigan has more than 25 years of stand-up experience behind her. Her jokes about a drinking in Ireland, her obsession with Malaysia Airlines flight 370, and her strategies to keep your kid out of ISIS make for a PG-13 (at most) affair. 
If you’re looking for a special you can enjoy without worrying if Mom wanders into the living room, Bothering Jesus is your best bet. 
Madigan’s conversational tone gives her an Irish pub bartender vibe. She’s never has to stretch for laughs. Her impressions (especially of parents) are charming, her accents are spot-on, she never runs out of creative ways to express her love for beer, and her jokes are just plain endearing. So don’t be fooled: Just because Bothering Jesus is the most family- oriented special on the list doesn’t mean it won’t make you spill a Guinness all over the couch. Tom Segura: Mostly Stories 
Tom Segura knows that story telling is his biggest strength. He tells the type of stories you’ll inevitably try and fail to recreate to friends—t. The kind where he yells back and forth with parents who brought their babies to movie theaters, or visits a strip club named B“beef,” or gets a cell-phone call from Mike Tyson after meeting him on a flight. You really can’t make this stuff up–though Segura sprinkles in subtle bits of fiction. Even hearing him retell his favorite episode of Beyond Scared Straight can bring tears of laughter. 
When Segura deviates from the stories he’s admittedly on shakier ground. His segment on racism is pretty rough, and though his imitation of a person who patronizes the handicapped is well intentioned, it’s still a bit clumsy. Luckily these parts are few and far in between, sandwiched by some truly hilarious stories. Dwayne Perkins: Take Note 
Dwayne Perkins is a thinking man’s comic. In Take Note , he steers clear of the usual cursing or needlessly offensive material most comics use to pad their first specials and relies on his talent for poking at people’s perceptions. He casually flips stereotypes on their heads, like when he declares white people the best dancers because “they have more fun.” After talking U.S. foreign policy, he takes an extra second to make fun of both the conservative and liberal response to his bit. And just try using his criterion of what makes a game a sport or an activity while watching ESPN2. Take Note treads the same ground Fresh Prince or Martin might’ve if they had lasted into 2016. 
Take Note has been 10 years in the making. Perkins, based in L.A. via Brooklyn, has been honing his skills on Comedy Central, Conan, Leno, and Carson Daly all the while. He’s probably the least well-known comic on the list, but he won’t be for long.

thread.title: The 12 Must-Watch Movies That Expire From Netflix in December 2016
thread.title_full: The 12 Must-Watch Movies That Expire From Netflix in December 2016

posts.title: The 12 Must-Watch Movies That Expire From Netflix in December 2016
posts.text: By Nick Schager Nov 23, 2016 There's never a busier time for cinephiles than December, when the studios decide to unload a year's worth of A-list works in theaters . That, coupled with the usual onslaught of fresh streaming options, means there's scant opportunity to see everything you want—much less make sure you're not missing a chance to catch those Netflix titles about to disappear from the service. Fortunately, this month's collection of departing movies is relatively light on classics, and below we've got a rundown of the ones you should most make time to see.   American Beauty (December 1) Most Popular Sam Mendes' Oscar winner (for Best Picture, Director, Actor, Screenplay, and Cinematography) stars Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening as a couple coping with crushing suburban discontent. Don't Be A Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice In the Hood (December 1) Produced by Keenen Ivory Wayans and starring his brothers Shawn and Marlon, this amusing spoof of '90s African-American coming-of-age movies set the stage for the actors' subsequent Scary Movie series. Elizabeth: The Golden Age (December 1)   Cate Blanchett reprises her role as Queen Elizabeth I of England in Shekhar Kapur's lavish 2007 sequel, which earned the star an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress. Event Horizon (December 1) Recounting the nightmarish ordeal suffered by a crew of astronauts after they discover a long-missing ship with an experimental gravity drive, Paul W. S. Anderson's stellar 1997 sci-fi/horror hybrid (starring Sam Neill and Laurence Fishburne) operates like a cross between Alien and Hellraiser .   Neil Young: Heart of Gold (December 1) Most Popular Jonathan Demme reconfirmed his status as modern cinema's finest concert-movie director with this masterful 2006 effort detailing Neil Young's two shows at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee in August 2005. Paycheck (December 1) Even in a formulaic sci-fi thriller like this (based on Philip K. Dick's short story), John Woo–here working with Ben Affleck and Uma Thurman–shows that he's one of the action genre's most accomplished filmmakers. Top Gun (December 1)   Tom Cruise hits the highway to the danger zone –with Kelly McGillis, Val Kilmer, and Anthony Edwards in tow–in Tony Scott's still-awesome 1986 military action hit. World Trade Center (December 1) Nicolas Cage is a Port Authority Police Officer who finds himself trapped in the rubble of New York City's Twin Towers on 9/11 in Oliver Stone's stirring (and surprisingly non-preachy) 2006 drama. Holes (December 5) Shia LaBeouf first proved that he had the talent to headline an A-list big-screen adventure with this 2003 adaptation of Louis Sachar's book (co-starring Sigourney Weaver, Jon Voight, Patricia Arquette, and Tim Blake Nelson) about a group of juvenile detention kids forced by their warden to dig holes in an empty lakebed.   Dark Skies (December 22) Most Popular Keri Russell and Josh Hamilton are a married couple whose lives are hopelessly disrupted, and whose children wind up in peril, after the arrival of mysterious alien visitors in this sturdy 2013 sci-fi thriller. Just Friends (December 26) Ryan Reynolds is a former fat outcast who returns to his hometown hoping to reconnect with his high-school crush (Amy Smart), even as he deals with a wild pop star (Anna Faris) in his custody, in this 2005 rom-com. Spy Kids (December 27) Robert Rodriguez's kids franchise may have increasingly gone off the rails with its subsequent sequels, but 2001's original–about two siblings (Daryl Sabara and Alexa Vega) who must save their spy parents (Carla Gugino and Antonio Banderas)–remains a cheeky, outlandish family affair. The full list of movies leaving Netflix in December are below: 12/1/16

thread.title: Steven Avery of 'Making a Murderer' Receives New Evidence Testing
thread.title_full: Steven Avery of 'Making a Murderer' Receives New Evidence Testing

posts.author: Hypebeast (info@hypebeast.com)
posts.title: Steven Avery of 'Making a Murderer' Receives New Evidence Testing
posts.text:
Last Christmas season, we all binge-watched Netflix's true crime documentary Making a Murderer . The show surrounding the story of the mysterious death of Teresa Halbach has been confirmed for a second season , which will continue to focus on the convictions of her alleged murderer, Steven Avery. This follows the major announcement by Avery’s lawyer, Kathleen Zellner, that an agreement to start independent scientific testing on critical pieces of evidence has been signed. This agreement comes nearly three months after Zellner planned to have the 2007 murder conviction overturned.
The new testing will include key pieces of evidence such as the spare key from Halbach's car found inside Avery's bedroom, as well as Avery's blood sample. Avery was sentenced to life in prison after being convicted of first-degree intentional homicide in the 2005 death of photographer Teresa Halbach in Manitowoc County, Wisconsin. Earlier this month, a judge granted the release of Brendan Dassey, Avery’s nephew, who was convicted in 2007 of helping Avery allegedly rape, kill and mutilate Halbach. Make sure to stay tuned for season two of Making a Murderer .
Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast.com

thread.title: ‘Gilmore Girls’ are back – on Netflix
thread.title_full: ‘Gilmore Girls’ are back – on Netflix

posts.title: ‘Gilmore Girls’ are back – on Netflix
posts.text:
‘Gilmore Girls’ are back – on Netflix | 
The familiar voices float softly from a black screen, as if in a dream. 
There’s Luke, gruffly: “How many cups have you had this morning?” 
And this parent-child banter: “Did you do something slutty?” Rory teasingly asks her mom. “I’m not THAT happy,” shoots back Lorelai. 
Thankfully, it’s not imagined. It’s the reality of “Gilmore Girls,” returning Friday after a nine-year absence, during which longtime fans pined for what they’d lost and newcomers discovered what they’d missed through reruns. 
Opening-credit snippets of the show’s hallmark dialogue kick off Netflix’s sequel to the 2000-07 broadcast series with a promise: the characters, their snappy banter and the show’s key notes will be honored. 
But the four-part “Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life” is aimed at more than true believers, creator Amy Sherman-Palladino said in an interview. 
“We want it to be something that fans are going to know, but if you haven’t watched ‘Gilmore,’ you can come to it fresh and take it on face value: It’s a story of three women, an intergenerational, multigenerational story, and you are catching them at times that each of their lives is changing.” 
That trio around which the universe rotates consists of devoted single mom Lorelai Gilmore (Lauren Graham), her equally devoted daughter Rory (Alexis Bledel) and stern grandmother Emily (Kelly Bishop). As the first chapter opens, Lorelai and Rory are still the belles of fictional Connecticut hamlet Stars Hollow – so perfect, quips Lorelai, it belongs in a snow globe. 
Luke (Scott Patterson), Lorelai’s on-again, off-again love is here, as are the supporting characters who gave the show, well, character. That includes official town nudge Taylor (now lobbying for a sewer system); reliably idiosyncratic Kirk (he’s just launched Ooober, a nonapp version of Uber) and even, in one episode, buoyant chef Sookie (courtesy of film star Melissa McCarthy’s return to her TV roots). 
Whatever bliss viewers find in the girl-power dramedy’s resurrection may be exceeded only by that of Sherman-Palladino, who wrote and produced it with Dan Palladino, her husband and creative partner on the sequel and the original. 
There’s a sad shadow, however, cast by the passing of family head Richard Gilmore. That reflects the December 2014 death of Edward Herr-mann, the respected actor who played him in the original series. 
The 90-minute episodes follow the seasons and are titled for each, starting with “Winter.” While Lorelai and Emily face Richard’s death in their own way, they also find their relationship affected by it. 
Given that all the episodes will be made available at once on streaming service Netflix, Sherman-Palladino sees trouble on the horizon. 
After holding close the four words she’s long said should end the Gilmore saga (she wasn’t in charge of the show’s last season on the CW network), she wants viewers to avoid spoiling the experience, either by posting the phrase or by impatiently jumping to the final scene. 
“It’s going to mean a lot more if you’ve taken the journey, and it’s going to mean a lot less if you just flip to the last page. ... It’s a fun trip. It’s worth it,” she said.

thread.title: Report: Netflix is paying Dave Chappelle $60 million for comedy specials
thread.title_full: Report: Netflix is paying Dave Chappelle $60 million for comedy specials

posts.title: Report: Netflix is paying Dave Chappelle $60 million for comedy specials
posts.text:
Report: Netflix is paying Dave Chappelle $60 million for comedy specials Posted by Liam McGuire on Nov 24, 2016 14:00 Dave Chappelle was a valuable asset for Comedy Central a decade ago, and as it turns out, he’s still a major draw in 2016. 
The legendary comedian returned to the spotlight a few weeks back, hosting one of the most poignant, memorable Saturday Night Live episodes in recent memory. With the show being a critical success , Chappelle’s comeback after leaving Chappelle’s Show in 2006 is in full-force, especially once it was announced he’d be doing comedy specials for Netflix . 
What wasn’t known, though, was how much Netflix offered Chappelle to bring him back. The answer? 
A whole lot of money, according to Page Six : 
“Dave was offered $20 million a special,” an unnamed source told Page Six. “Netflix basically has a war chest for this kind of content. Whether it’s a loss or not, Dave Chappelle’s specials will get a lot of press and bring in new subscribers.” 
It might seem like an insane cost, but Netflix hasn’t been shy about spending serious coin to get premium content. The networks early successful drama House of Cards reportedly cost $4.5 million per episode . Netflix also reportedly paid Chris Rock the same $20 million per special rate as Chappelle for his two releases. 
Regardless of the cost, Dave Chappelle returning to comedy is something for which we can all be thankful. 
Welcome back, Dave. 
[ Business Insider ] About Liam McGuire Staff writer for The Comeback. I also write for Awful Announcing and Vice Sports. I previously worked for TSN Radio 1050 and TSN Analytics. Proudly born in Nova Scotia, Canada. Email --> LiamMcGuirejournalism GMAIL.com

thread.title: Here are 5 shows on Netflix, Amazon you should binge watch after Thanksgiving - Press Enterprise
thread.title_full: Here are 5 shows on Netflix, Amazon you should binge watch after Thanksgiving - Press Enterprise

posts.author: SHANNON O'CONNOR
posts.title: Here are 5 shows on Netflix, Amazon you should binge watch after Thanksgiving - Press Enterprise
posts.text:
By SHANNON O'CONNOR / STAFF WRITER
Published: Nov. 24, 2016 Updated: 3:04 p.m. Here are 5 shows on Netflix, Amazon you should binge watch after Thanksgiving Print Photo Share Pin It More Galleries Rachel Bloom, left, stars as Rebecca Bunch and Santino Fontana stars as Greg Serrano in "Crazy Ex-Girlfriend." EDDY CHEN, THE CW Related article » The dishes have been licked clean, the football games have ended and the turkey coma is finally setting in, so what is there to do now? Binge-watch some TV.
There is no better day to indulge in the cultural phenomenon than the day after Thanksgiving. So jump in (or stay in) your pajamas, find a comfy position on the couch and boot up Netflix or Amazon to one (or, if you are feeling adventurous, all) of these shows.
"Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life"
It’s back! After months of hype and promotion, the four new 90-minute installments of “Gilmore Girls” are finally here . Take a trip back to Stars Hollow, Connecticut, and revisit Lorelai, Rory, Emily, Luke and all the other colorful townsfolk fans have come to adore. Whether you have been a long-time Gilmore fan or are just discovering the series (in this case, bonus because you get to binge more!) these installments should provide some laughs, tears and nostalgia. To accompany this binge, I suggest copious amounts of coffee, pop tarts and tater tots. Also keep pizza and tacos nearby, you know, just in case. All previous seasons are currently streaming on Netflix and the new episodes arrive on Nov. 25 at 12:01 a.m.
"Good Girls Revolt"
In the past few weeks journalism has been an issue of much discussion, so there is no better time to dive into Amazon’s new series “Good Girls Revolt.” The series is loosely based on Lynn Povich’s book of the same name and is a fictionalized account of Povich and her female co-workers' struggle with a sexual discrimination case against Newsweek magazine over pay and gender equality in 1969. Though the show is set a few decades in the past, it brings to light many issues still plaguing women in the workforce today (ahem, the pay gap). All episodes of the series first season are available on Amazon.
"Crazy Ex-Girlfriend"
Musical lovers and people who love a good Southern California joke or reference, here's a show for you. Rachel Bloom’s “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend” is the musical-comedy extravaganza about a young New York hotshot lawyer who uproots her high-powered life to follow her old high school boyfriend back to West Covina only to find that he is in a serious relationship. Laughs, heartbreak and big (paradoxical) musical numbers ensue, but it is the heart in the show that will keep you coming back (although the music is pretty catchy, too). All episodes of the first season are available for streaming on Netflix. Season 2 is currently airing on The CW.
"Black Mirror"
If you are in the mood for some more serious TV fare, try the bizarre but captivating anthology series “Black Mirror.” The series, which returned for a 6-episode third season late last month, tackles complex storylines that contribute to society’s greatest fears, including blackmail, technology and social media. And be ready for some twists and surprises. The show may make you paranoid, but just remember it is fiction (for now). All episodes are streaming on Netflix.
“The Crown”
Though at this point you may be a bit tired of politics and government, Netflix’s latest series “The Crown” about Queen Elizabeth II shouldn't be missed. Though we have seen versions of the Queen’s life on screen before, this 10-part series not only focuses on the life of Elizabeth herself but the lives of those around her. Fans of series such as “The Tudors” or “Reign” will undoubtedly be drawn to this British monarchy tale that has critics raving. All episodes of the first season are streaming on Netflix.
Related: 'Gilmore Girls' stars Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel dish on new Netflix episodes Digital & Driveway Delivery - 50% Off

thread.title: What Time Does ‘Gilmore Girls’ Start on Netflix?
thread.title_full: What Time Does ‘Gilmore Girls’ Start on Netflix?

posts.author: laurenweigle
posts.title: What Time Does ‘Gilmore Girls’ Start on Netflix?
posts.text:
The revival series Gilmore Girls: A Year In the Life is set to be released at 3:00 a.m. Eastern time and midnight Pacific time on Friday, November 25, 2016 (technically, tonight). If that is too late for you to stay awake, you can watch it all at your convenience, just beware of spoilers. Click here to watch the new season once it begins on Netflix. 
Netflix’s official synopsis of the series reads: 
Set nearly a decade after the finale of the original series, this revival follows Lorelai, Rory and Emily Gilmore through four seasons of change.
Over the course of the mini-series, minus actor Edward Hermann who passed away in 2014, all of the men in Rory Gilmore’s life will return – Logan, Jess and Dean. And, all of the delightfully odd characters from the original television series are back as well. Even actress Melissa McCarthy has come back.
When it comes to the overall storyline, show-runner Amy Sherman-Pallidino told Entertainment Weekly , that Grandpa Richard Gilmore’s death will carry throughout the series. 
Actress Kelly Bishop, who plays Richard’s wife Emily, recalled found memories of having Hermann on set, telling EW : 
It’s sad without my darling Edward Herrmann. We used to do our crossword puzzle together in the makeup trailer. If we had a short day and were feeling festive or belligerent, we’d go across the street and have a martini together.
Scott Patterson, who plays Luke Danes on the show, added: 
[Herrmann’s death] left a big void, but Amy honored it beautifully. He’s throughout … these stories. It’s a wonderful homage to him as a person and to his character as well. It’s nice to have him around.
As for what to expect from the mini-series revival in terms of where the characters are in their lives on the show, Palladino told USA Today :
It had been enough time that all the stories seemed clear, where they would be, what they would be grappling with. If we had done it earlier, it might have been too soon. 
Actress Lauren Graham also stated: 
It’s been exactly like the old show and then completely new and different. Just a little grown up … That wonderful, fun language that’s so playful. We get to play a million different little characters within the character. It’s just been an overwhelmingly happy experience. I have been weirdly and inappropriately emotional the whole time.
So, now that you know what to expect and what time the show will be released, get ready for a year of the Gilmore Girls . And, though the series is set to be released at 3:00 a.m., Netflix has been known to surprise viewers with slightly early releases. So, you never know if it could come out a couple hours earlier. But, most likely, the show will premiere as scheduled.

thread.title: Netflix and LOLz: Michael Che’s Bringing the Laughs With Several Other Black Comics
thread.title_full: Netflix and LOLz: Michael Che’s Bringing the Laughs With Several Other Black Comics

posts.author: Genetta Adams
posts.title: Netflix and LOLz: Michael Che’s Bringing the Laughs With Several Other Black Comics
posts.text:
If you’ve seen Michael Che’s subtle and deadpan comedy as the co-host of Saturday Night Live ‘s “Weekend Update,” you’ll be surprised by his hilarious, take-no-prisoners style on controversial topics in his Netflix special, Michael Che Matters , which will premiere Friday on the streaming service.
Netflix is leading the charge ahead of networks like Comedy Central by hosting up-and-coming black comedians along with seasoned veterans. Che, who grew up on New York’s Lower East Side and was named after Che Guevara by his father (the comedian was born Michael Che Campbell), is one of several comedians who are part of Netflix’s rollout of comedy specials, including Cedric the Entertainer, whose special aired Sept. 16; Reggie Watts, whose special will air Dec. 6; and Gabriel Iglesias whose special will air Dec. 20. Chris Rock is returning to stand-up after an eight-year absence with two new specials for Netflix that will tape in 2017.
Netflix also dropped the bomb earlier this week that Dave Chappelle will be airing two never-before-seen specials that come directly from his personal comedy vault along with another show in 2017. He reportedly received $60 million for the deal.
For Che, 33, this will be his first comedy special. He has worked as a correspondent for The Daily Show , a writer and cast member for SNL and in 2014, became the first black co-anchor in the history of “Weekend Update.”
He brings an understated New York B-boy sensibility, dressed in a hoodie, jeans and Air Force 1s, and mixes it with a quirky take on serious issues like police brutality, homophobia, white Jesus, catcalling and white supremacy, all with unpredictable twists.
Che on the black man’s burdens of being called a n–ger and then having to fight: You can’t say, “I got my ass kicked for 15 minutes.”
On white supremacy and racism: “You know what kind of self-confidence you need to be a supremacist. You think Hitler had body-image issues?”
On saying All Lives Matter over Black Live Matters: “That’s like my wife asking me if I love her. Baby, I love everybody, what are you talking about?”
On police brutality: “Blacks and cops aren’t getting along. I don’t know if you’ve seen the news in the last 400 years.”
On white people asking can they say the n-word: “It’s like having an alcoholic ask for a sip of my drink. I don’t want to be responsible for what happens.”
On Jesus being black: “You insist on having that black baby. Well, keep him in the manger over there.”
Che’s special, Michael Che Matters , taped at Greenpoint Terminal Warehouse in Brooklyn, N.Y., airs Friday on Netflix.

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls' Returns On Netflix, Just In Time For A Holiday Binge
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls' Returns On Netflix, Just In Time For A Holiday Binge

posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls' Returns On Netflix, Just In Time For A Holiday Binge
posts.text:
'Gilmore Girls' Returns On Netflix, Just In Time For A Holiday Binge 'Gilmore Girls' Returns On Netflix, Just In Time For A Holiday Binge Audio will be available later today. 
Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel return for four movies continuing the Gilmore Girls story. Saeed Adyani/Netflix hide caption toggle caption Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel return for four movies continuing the Gilmore Girls story. Saeed Adyani/Netflix 
Most television shows arrive accompanied by the question, "Is it good?" Revivals of old shows, however, often arrive with the question, "Is it necessary?" 
The four new 90-minute installments of Gilmore Girls that arrived Friday on Netflix under the title Gilmore Girls: A Year In The Life fare better by that adjusted standard than most. Gilmore Girls , which ran from 2000 to 2007, was a good show, and because creator Amy Sherman-Palladino left before the seventh and final season following a contractual dispute, she didn't get to end it the way she wanted to. Moreover, the reason to watch Gilmore Girls was always to spend time in its constructed universe, observing the relationships it built, and listening to its stylish dialogue and its "la-la-la" music. Most of the frustrations were around plot developments, in fact; most of the pleasures came from being in the characters' company. To be in their company again feels very much like television's closest approximation of the same holiday catch-up that happens in real life — that's one of the reasons the Thanksgiving weekend release is such clever timing. Article continues after sponsorship 
We don't find Lorelai Gilmore (Lauren Graham) and her daughter Rory (Alexis Bledel) where we left them in 2007. The original series followed Lorelai from the 32-year-old mom of a 16-year-old to the almost-40 mom of a college graduate, and now Lorelai is pushing 50 and Rory is a grown, published writer. Time has been allowed to pass in their lives, and in the lives of everyone they knew. 
The biggest change in Gilmore world is that Lorelai's father, Richard, has passed away like Edward Herrmann, who played him. This leaves Lorelai's mother, Emily — beautifully performed without so much as a dropped beat by the divine Kelly Bishop — to find a path forward without her husband of 50 years. As much as Herrmann is missed, and he is missed, the mother-daughter relationships between Emily and Lorelai and Lorelai and Rory have always been the best reason to watch Gilmore Girls . Sherman-Palladino, like any good writer, uses the grief that can't be avoided to tell new stories and to push particularly Lorelai's relationship with her mother to new places. And that, again, plays to the show's longtime strengths: other shows had snappy dialogue and other shows embraced quirky small towns, but very few writers cared about moms and daughters with the depth and focus that Sherman-Palladino did. 
It's sort of funny, then, that so much of the chatter around the revival has been around revisiting the long-arc love story of Lorelai and Luke, and — inevitably — squabbling over the prospects of Rory's assorted disappointing boyfriends. For many women, the expectation that if you're single at the end of college, you are destined to either remain so or return to a man you already know would be alarming. But for Rory, there's a lot of fan talk about preferences as between Dean (the nice-guy first boyfriend turned disastrous affair), Jess (the rebellious second boyfriend), and Logan (the rich Yalie boyfriend). All return for the revival, but not in equal measure. As in life, some ghosts hang around, and some do not. I wouldn't dream of giving away the game here, but I will say that my own sympathies regarding The Legion Of Disappointing Boyfriends are not the same as they were when all these young men were younger men. And that's true to life, as well. 
Sherman-Palladino has always been an idiosyncratic creator; that's what makes her work special. The bargain, though, is that every idiosyncratic creator will baffle you at some point with an offbeat idea that seems not to belong. There are a couple of those sequences here, particularly in the middle two segments, "Spring" and "Summer," both of which have their writing and direction credited to Sherman-Palladino's husband, Daniel Palladino (the two collaborated on the original show as well). Some of these are easier to forgive given that they seem to arise from efforts to use guest stars well — particularly Sutton Foster, who starred in Sherman-Palladino's short-lived but dearly missed series Bunheads and who shows up in Stars Hollow under circumstances that it would be impolite to spoil and that, frankly, don't matter very much. There are actually a number of Bunheads -related sightings, which is entirely consistent with the truism that whatever else is said about Sherman-Palladino's work, it's never less than fully transparent how dearly she loves it and how personally she takes it. In fact, that's one of the reasons it's good to see her wrap up this story as she intended, even independent of whether it entirely pleases you or not. 
A friend of mine coined the term "anticippointment" to describe the way eagerness to return to a show like this often gives way to a realization that it couldn't quite give you everything you hoped for. This revival is not immune. Four 90-minute episodes amount to about the same running time as maybe eight and a half vintage Gilmore Girls episodes, or a little more than a third of a season. And in that third of a season, they have seven seasons of history to acknowledge, ignore, recall, or expand upon. They've also got to establish what's happened in the last nine years, complete three major storylines (Lorelai's, Rory's and Emily's), and perform a lot of what's derisively known as "fan service" — giving the people what they want. The people want to see Mrs. Kim again, and Babette, and Kirk, and if those names aren't meaningful to you, this revival probably isn't intended for you, particularly. 
The good news is that if you're not a Gilmore Girls person and your relatives are eager to watch it over the holidays, there's plenty of that staccato dialogue and family playfulness to entertain and divert you. It just won't resonate the way it might if you've been watching since Rory wore her private-school uniform and formed her first friendships.

posts.author: Rolend
posts.title: Re: Thanksgiving Horror Film Kristy Lands on Netflix
posts.text:
Thanksgiving Horror Film Kristy Lands on Netflix Posted on Pinterest Stumbleupon Pocket Tumblr Google Subscribe 
The release strategy for Oliver Blackburn’s Kristy has been anything but conventional, as the film finally premiered on Lifetime last month – two years after making a splash at the 2013 AFM. Those who missed it will be happy to learn that it’s now available for instant streaming on Netflix. 
Read on for everything you need to know before streaming! 
From director Oliver “Olly” Blackburn ( Donkey Punch ) and producers David Kirschner (the Child’s Play series), Corey Sienega ( Frailty, Bride of Chucky, Seed of Chucky ), and Jamie Patricof and Lynette Howell ( Blue Valentine, Place Beyond the Pines ), comes a new thriller starring Haley Bennett ( Music and Lyrics ), Ashley Greene ( The Twilight Saga, The Apparition ), Erica Ash ( Scary Movie 5 ), Lucas Till ( X-Men: First Class ), and Chris Coy (TV’s “True Blood”). Anthony Jaswinski ( Vanishing on 7th Street ) penned the script. 
Synopsis: With the rest of the campus at home for the Thanksgiving holiday, Justine (Bennett) and a few of her friends spend the weekend in their college dormitory: studying, relaxing, and blissfully unaware of the terror that is about to unfold outside in the cold. Suddenly, confronted by a gang of violent outcasts, Justine’s quiet weekend becomes one long lesson in survival as she and her classmates are terrorized in increasingly bizarre and brutal ways, leaving it up to her to figure out who the attackers are… and if they can be stopped. thread.title: Gilmore Girls reveals those final four words as the Netflix revival reaches a dramatic climax
thread.title_full: Gilmore Girls reveals those final four words as the Netflix revival reaches a dramatic climax

posts.author: Morgan Jeffery
posts.title: Gilmore Girls reveals those final four words as the Netflix revival reaches a dramatic climax
posts.text: 13 hours ago 10:02 PM © Netflix 25 November 2016 11:24 AM Shares Warning: This article contains spoilers for the Gilmore Girls revival - and particularly the final episode. Read at your own risk! It's been a long wait... but the final four words of Gilmore Girls have finally been revealed. Series creator Amy Sherman-Palladino has apparently always known exactly how the show would wrap up - and got to deliver her vision in 'Fall'. © Netflix Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The final instalment of the Netflix revival ended with Lorelai (Graham) and Rory (Alexis Bledel) sitting together on a gazebo - shortly after Lorelai and Luke (Scott Patterson) finally tied the knot. But Rory had some surprising news to deliver... "Mom?" "Yeah?" "I'm pregnant." So there you have it. But who's the daddy? Odds are it's Rory's dud boyfriend Paul (Jack Carpenter) - though Logan (Matt Czuchry) could be a contender. Sherman-Palladino told the Hollywood Reporter that she found the "emotional moment" very "satisfying" after so long. "We really had a very specific journey in our minds and we fulfilled the journey. So to us, this is the piece that we wanted to do." © Netflix So does that mean another trip to Stars Hollow is a no-go? Even though A Year in the Life ends on something of a cliffhanger? Lauren Graham told Digital Spy that it's " hard to say " whether Gilmore Girls will come back... again. "I'll be curious when all the episodes are out because this feels like such a grassroots thing – the people brought Gilmore Girls back so I think it's up to the people if they think the ending feels satisfying enough. "If it does I wouldn't want to touch it. To me it ends in a really satisfying way that could also continue... so I guess we'll see." Want up-to-the-minute entertainment and tech news? Just hit 'Like' on our Digital Spy Facebook page and 'Follow' on our @digitalspy Twitter account and you're all set.

thread.title: Jimmy Fallon Grills His Favorite 'Gilmore Girls' Characters on the Show's Final Four Words
thread.title_full: Jimmy Fallon Grills His Favorite 'Gilmore Girls' Characters on the Show's Final Four Words

posts.author: The Hollywood Reporter
posts.title: Jimmy Fallon Grills His Favorite 'Gilmore Girls' Characters on the Show's Final Four Words
posts.text:
Jimmy Fallon has plenty of theories for the long-rumored final four words in Netflix's upcoming Gilmore Girls revival.
Sitting down Tuesday with Gilmore Girls' Luke, Kirk and Paris (Scott Patterson, Sean Gunn and Liza Weil), Fallon pitched his ideas for the last scene as well. Fallon even started off the segment with his own rendition of his new favorite show's theme song by Carol King.
"I'm freaking out," Fallon said in announcing his favorite three characters. Calling it the "best show ever," Fallon confirmed that "every night I go to sleep to Gilmore Girls." He's currently on season five, and already has a theory about those last four words , said to have been showrunner Amy Sherman-Palladino's plan for the show all along. Is the whole town inside a snow globe?
Read more: 'Gilmore Girls' "Epic" Final Four Words: Cast Shares Their Predictions
Welcoming three of his favorite Gilmore Girls characters, Fallon grilled the trio on those rumored final words.
Gunn said he still doesn't know what they are. "I want to watch it with the fans and see," he told Fallon. "Maybe it's 'Kirk is your overlord.' "
Patterson said he pitched "Drop the gun, Kirk," but Sherman-Palladino rejected his idea. Fallon's idea? "Stars Hollow never existed."
On the Netflix revival, which debuts Nov. 25, Patterson said the outpouring of excitement from the fans now is touching, but not too surprising. "The fans see it as a religion, it's not just a show to them," he explained. "And we knew during the original run how the fans were reacting to it, so it's not really a surprise."
Gunn agreed, adding that "it feels like the show is more popular now than it ever was. So to hear fans are so excited for it, for a show that we did 15 years ago, it's crazy."
Weil said it was "bizarre to go back" to the show after leaving her character of Paris so long ago and moving on to ABC's How to Get Away With Murder. Patterson told Fallon that he had to take a walk around the town before being able to find his character again.
Last week, the Tonight Show host updated the audience on his binge-watching of the original series (he was still on season four) and listed his favorite characters . Taylor Doose, Luke, Kirk and Sookie all made the cut, with his all-time favorite being Paris Geller (Weil), Rory Gilmore's friend and rival.
Watch the video below.
Read more: 'Gilmore Girls': 9 Big Takeaways From the Netflix Revival Trailer

thread.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Season 2 Release Date, Cast And Millie Bobby Brown’s Return
thread.title_full: ‘Stranger Things’ Season 2 Release Date, Cast And Millie Bobby Brown’s Return

posts.author: Frank Yemi
posts.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Season 2 Release Date, Cast And Millie Bobby Brown’s Return
posts.text:
Frank Yemi 
Season 2 of Stranger Things has been confirmed and the anticipated Netflix original has a lot more in store for fans. The air date is expected in 2017 and while no official release date has been announced, it is expected that Netflix will continue its original scheduled lineup and release it around July 2017. Finn Wolfhard for Dazed Magazine #StrangerThings pic.twitter.com/pH4uve4BAQ 
— MEFeater Magazine (@mefeater) November 23, 2016 
Millie Bobby Brown is returning as Eleven; however, it is still unclear if she will be a regular or a guest star as the series have added several additional cast members. Stranger Things creators The Duffer Brothers revealed that they may change some of the titles for season 2 because they don’t want to give too much away. 
Millie Bobby Brown’s Eleven is one of the biggest secrets of Stranger Things Season 2. In an interview, David Harbour, who plays Hopper, confirmed that the Eggo waffles he leaves in the season finale are in fact for Eleven. He revealed that his character believes that Eleven exist in “some form,” which suggest the beloved character may not be herself when she returns in season 2. Linnea Berthelsen has joined the cast of 'Stranger Things' as a character named Roman! It's lit. #StrangerThings pic.twitter.com/ZxL4ZItaTr 
— Geeks Of Color (@GeeksOfColor) November 8, 2016 
There are several new cast members joining in season 2 of Stranger Things . Two new characters Max played by actress Sadie Sink and Billy played by Dacre Montgomery will be siblings. The first episode of season 2 is titled “Madmax”, which provides some insight to a character who is described as “a tough and confident girl whose appearance, behavior, and pursuits seem more typical of boys than of girls in this era. She has a complicated history and is generally suspicious of those around her,” according to The Hollywood Reporter . Sadie Sink will play tomboy Max, and Dacre Montgomery will play step-brother Billy in Season 2 of Stranger Things. pic.twitter.com/HX3QeMe6w5 
— Anne (@momsfilms) October 16, 2016 
Her step-brother Billy is more of a bad boy who drives a black Camaro and it good with the ladies. Comedian Brett Gelman will join the cast of season two to play a conspiracy theorist and disgraced journalist Murray Bauman who shows up in Hawkins, Indiana – a very strange town that could potentially prove a story he is chasing. Comedian Brett Gelman is bringing some conspiracy theory to STRANGER THINGS season 2! https://t.co/7YU4Vf4ask pic.twitter.com/gush4TzEEy 
— ComicBook NOW! (@ComicBookNOW) November 18, 2016 
The Duffer brother have revealed that there are a lot of details about the Upside Down world that will slowly be introduced as the series progresses. The show will continue it’s 80’s themed plot and draw inspiration from popular pop culture classics of that era. Just when you thought #StrangerThings couldn't get more '80s … https://t.co/waJg5hjPla 
— Mashable (@mashable) November 7, 2016 
The Stranger Things kids included Will Byers are expected to return and have been photographed filming scenes from season 2 of Stranger Things . Due to the maturation of the young cast members, the second season will begin about 12 months after the events of the first season’s finale. The Duffer Brothers have said that the time jump will be explained and viewers will have to put some of the pieces together as the episodes progress. 
Nancy Wheeler and Jonathan may not end up together but the writers have not written off the idea. Many fans are hoping that recovering d-bag Steve Harrington blows it with Nancy so that she could be with Jonathan. Barbara will also get some form of justice; however, she will remain dead. 
Another mystery of Stranger Things Season 2 is whether the monster is dead or there is more of them out there. Some fans are making theories based off the titles for the episodes, which sort of confirms that the next season will feature nine episodes as follows: 
1 – Madmax 
2 – The Boy Who Came Back to Life 
3 – The Pumpkin Patch

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls' Creator and Stars Discuss Final Four Words: "It Made Complete Sense"
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls' Creator and Stars Discuss Final Four Words: "It Made Complete Sense"

posts.author: The Hollywood Reporter
posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls' Creator and Stars Discuss Final Four Words: "It Made Complete Sense"
posts.text:
[Warning: This story contains spoilers from the fourth and final installment of Netflix's Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, "Fall."]
The final four words have finally been spoken.
For nearly a decade, Gilmore Girls fans have been clamoring to find out the final four words that creator Amy Sherman-Palladino wanted the series to end with. When Netflix officially greenlit the four-part revival, Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, last January, it not only represented a chance for die-hard viewers to get to revisit Stars Hollow and catch up with all their favorite residents, but much more importantly, a chance to finally see just how Sherman-Palladino intended for the beloved series to wrap.
Everyone, that is, except Lauren Graham.
"I didn't know it was a thing actually," Graham told The Hollywood Reporter about the highly anticipated final scene. "I didn't know until halfway through filming this that those existed and then Amy told them to me on the set. I was surprised for a minute and then it made complete sense."
The fourth and final 90-minute chapter of the revival, titled "Fall," ended with Lorelai (Graham) and Rory (Alexis Bledel) sitting together in the gazebo mere hours after Lorelai and Luke (Scott Patterson) finally tied the knot. Rory (finally) got dumped from her basically non-existent and very unmemorable boyfriend Paul but as Lorelai reassured her that both she and Paul would find their "someone amazing," Rory began to look increasingly distraught. Then, Rory turned to her mother suddenly. "Mom?" she said. "Yeah," Lorelai responded. "I'm pregnant," Rory said. Cue a profile shot of Lorelai's stunned face and then the screen cut to the credits, with the iconic theme song playing.
Read more: 'Gilmore Girls' Team Open Up About Netflix Revival and "Journey" to Those Final Four Words
Although the final four words were never written down in the script for "Fall," Graham said she was still reluctant to read the script for the final installment and find out just how things would wrap up.
"I had a very general sense of where Lorelai was that made complete sense to me and then, what I didn't know exactly is how it would end," Graham recalled. "For the longest time, I couldn't read 'Fall,' which is our last episode. I was like, 'This is psychotic, I have to read where this ends up,' but I think I was both worried it wouldn't be satisfying and also just kind of wanted to save it. Eventually, I read it and it was very satisfying."
When it came time to actually film the famed final four words, Bledel said she felt "a lot of pressure to get it right, to make it awesome. More than anything, I was just trying to be really focused and really present just to make sure that whatever I did in the scene felt rooted in my experience of the character and I was communicating something that felt real to me."
Looking back, Sherman-Palladino said it was an "interesting" experience finally seeing the words that had been living in her head come to life so many years later.
Read more: 'Gilmore Girls' "Epic" Final Four Words: Cast Shares Their Predictions
"It was emotional for like Lauren, Alexis, [executive producer] Dan [Palladino] and me, but you're surrounded by a giant crew that only care about lunch and they want to move on and the [director of photography]'s losing the light, the [production assistants] are all talking to each other or on their headphones and we're trying to get the extras to shut up…"
Palladino chimed in: "You're surrounded by people that don't give a flying f-."
However, Sherman-Palladino said there was a silver lining to filming the highly anticipated moment under such "weird" circumstances, as she herself called it. "Otherwise it would just be a sob fest and we'd all be like lying on the ground waiting until the valium arrived."
Despite years of build-up, Sherman-Palladino said the final scene lived up to her expectations. "It was satisfying in the context of when we put it altogether," she said. "It's an emotional moment."
But will that emotional - and surprising - moment really be the end of Gilmore Girls? As Sherman-Palladino previously told THR , she's waiting to see just how viewers embrace A Year in the Life before plotting a next move.
"We really had a very specific journey in our minds and we fulfilled the journey. So to us, this is the piece that we wanted to do. And the whole thought about, is there more, is there more, is there more - this has to go out into the universe now," Sherman-Palladino said. "And then whatever happens, happens."
What did you think of the final four words? Do you want to see more new episodes? Share your thoughts in the comments below.

thread.title: Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life: The Amazing Behind-the-Scenes Story of Amy and Dan's Revival Pitch to Netflix
thread.title_full: Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life: The Amazing Behind-the-Scenes Story of Amy and Dan's Revival Pitch to Netflix

posts.author: Michael Ausiello
posts.title: Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life: The Amazing Behind-the-Scenes Story of Amy and Dan's Revival Pitch to Netflix
posts.text: gg2 More In lieu of a second Gilmore Girls revival, perhaps Netflix could just release footage of Team Palladino’s initial pitch for A Year in the Life ? Because we have a hunch it would play very well with audiences. RELATED Gilmore Girls Revival Ends on a Cliffhanger?! Plus: Lorelai and Luke Are Definitely Not [Spoiler] As exec producer Daniel Palladino tells me, he and series creator Amy Sherman-Palladino prepared an hour-long pitch for the four-part continuation and presented it to three outlets (including the winning suitor, Netflix). At each of the three meetings, “It was me, Amy and a couple of Warner Bros. executives,” Palladino shares. “And we went into some detail.” That’s putting it mildly. “Amy and I would perform certain key dialogue moments — especially comedic ones where describing them just wouldn’t do it justice — with a performance,” he explains. “Otherwise, over the course of the hour it would’ve gotten very dull. There were whole monologues of Lorelai’s that Amy would perform. I would sometimes play Lorelai, too. And sometimes we would recite dialogue back and forth. And sometimes we would stand. That’s how we always pitch things — with a lot of dialogue and a lot of performance.” The duo — who wrote and directed all four 90-minute revival chapters (which drop this Friday at 3:01 am EST) — went into the pitching sessions with only a verbal commitment from the cast. “We talked to the principal four — Lauren [Graham], Alexis [Bledel], Scott [Patterson]and Kelly [Bishop],” notes Palladino. “And we asked them, ‘If we were to do this, would you do it?’ If one of them said they absolutely wouldn’t do it, we would not have proceeded.” Check back in the coming hours and days for more from Stars Hollow’s elite as TVLine’s “ 18 Days of Gilmore ” scoop countdown continues.
